The development of bifunctional oxygen electrode electrocatalysis for both the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) plays a vital role in the solution of the energy crisis as well as the environmental pollution. The purpose of this paper is to investigate the potential of graphene-supported lanthanum oxide clusters (La2O3-Gra) as a bifunctional electrocatalyst; the results show that the optimal catalytic site (up-down1) of the most stable configuration (O-Gra-1) modified by OH group shows outstanding bifunctional catalytic activity with ηORR of 0.51 V and ηOER of 0.52 V, which can be compared to the commercial Pt-based ORR catalysts and the Ru/Ir-oxides OER catalysts. Furthermore, there is a strong scale-dependent relationship between the adsorption free energy (ΔGads) of reaction intermediates, resulting in volcano plots between the catalytic activity and ΔGads, which provides a valuable description for future performance prediction of structurally similar catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxygen reduction reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Lanthanum oxide cluster Density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Traditional fossil energy use is closely linked to the rapid development of modern societies. Yet the subsequent depletion of energy and pollution of the environment will in turn restrict the further development of society [1,2]. Humanity urgently needs environmentally friendly and renewable alternative energy to replace conventional fossil fuels. Technologies for storing and converting electrochemical energy, such as renewable fuel cells [3] and rechargeable metal-air batteries [4], have the advantages of safety, greenness, pollution-free and high-power density, which play a critical role in addressing the above issues. Unfortunately, the slow kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in the oxygen electrodes severely hamper the overall reaction efficiency of the batteries, leading to the demand for electrocatalysis. Traditionally, platinum-based catalysts have been considered to be effective catalysts for ORR; [5–7] the oxides of ruthenium (Ru) and iridium (Ir) are known as outstanding OER catalysts [8–10]. However, the scarcity, high-cost, low stability, easy CO poisoning and single catalytic function hinder the further commercial application of the technology. Therefore, it is meaningful to develop green, efficient, safe, durable, low-pollution and low-cost bifunctional electrocatalysis for ORR and OER. In recent years, research on single-atom catalysts (SACs) is widespread due to the high atomic utilization [11] and high catalytic activity for either ORR or OER [12–21]. However, there are shortcomings in SACs as well [22]. As the metal particles are reduced to the monatomic level, the specific surface area increases sharply, leading to a large increase in the free energy of the metal surface, which means that it is very easy to agglomerate and to inactivate in the process of preparation and reaction. As a result, SACs face significant challenges to load capacity and stability. Metal nanoclusters, as a new type of nanomaterials with precise chemical composition and atomic structure, have attracted a great deal of attention due to their high surface volume ratio, tunable size and unsaturated coordination properties [23–25]. Compared to larger-sized nanoparticles, nanoclusters have a smaller size to expose more active sites. The stability of the nanocage clusters is also high, which is conducive to preventing the sintering and agglomeration of the catalyst in long-term work [26]. Graphene, as a two-dimensional material of sp2-hybridized carbon, has the advantages of high surface-area-to-volume ratio, high electrical conductivity, high ductility, high flexibility and good stability, and shows high selectivity, sustainability and high efficiency in electrocatalysis, is the ideal platform for supporting functional nanomaterials such as clusters [27–30]. For instance, Jalili et al. studied an Ag8 cluster deposited on nitrogen-doped graphene with theoretical calculation. It is found that supported Ag8 clusters exhibit excellent ORR activity because of higher charge transfer to O2 and significant decrease in O2 adsorption energy compared to unsupported clusters [31]. With a multi electronic structure, excellent magnetic, optical and electrical properties, rare earth elements (REEs) are widely used in many essential areas including catalysis, metallurgy, permanent magnets, lasers, and so forth [32–35]. Compared to precious metals REEs are not uncommon. World-proven reserves of rare earths (oxides) amount to 121 million metric tons [36], and even the lowest lutetium is almost 200 times greater than gold. Moreover, Turkey discovered 694 million tons of rare earth element reserves (minerals) not long ago. There are 17 different rare earth elements in the resource, which is the second largest reserve in the world, only surpassed by China's 800 million tons of reserves (minerals). REEs are known to be readily oxidized in nature. It is interesting to note that scientists found that oxidized REEs such as La2O3 [37,38], Eu2O3 [39,40], CeO2 [41,42] and so forth [43–47], have superior stability and excellent ORR or OER performance. Both of which could explain the excellent properties of these rare earth oxides. First, as a relatively independent block in the periodic table, the lanthanides have special 4f electronic structures, which contribute to the migration of 4f electrons between the f-f and f-d configurations, formation of unique bonding characteristics, reduction of activation energy, and ultimately promotion of the catalytic process [48–50]. Second, the formation of REE-O effectively regulates the electronic properties of the active centers and counteracts excessive adsorption of rare earth to reaction intermediates, which may be the primary reason for the excellent activity of the rare earth oxides. Zhao et al. [51] reported the superior activity of lanthanum oxide nanocrystals loaded N-doped porous carbon (La2O3/NPC) for ORR in alkalinity. La2O3/NPC was successfully prepared through the chemical deposition of CO(NH2)2 and LaCl3 and followed calcination. The hexagonal structure of La2O3 was confirmed by X-ray diffraction analyses. The Synthetic La2O3/NPC exhibits remarkable ORR activity, and the half-wave potential is 0.90 V, which is higher than that of the commercial Pt/C (0.83 V). What's else? Dai et al. [41] have constructed a CeO2 substrate supported CoS1.97 (CeO2-CoS1.97) and CoS1.97 with CeO2 surface decorated (CoS1.97-CeO2), respectively. Of these, CeO2-CoS1.97 exhibits a low overpotential of 264 mV at 10 mA·cm−2 due to the stable heterostructure and more rapid mass transfer. And CoS1.97-CeO2 has a smaller Tafel slope of 49 mV·dec−1 due to enhanced adsorption of OH group, rapid electron transfer, and in situ formation of Co(IV)O2 species under OER process. An efficient approach was taken in this paper to improve the utilization and loading capacity of rare earth elements and to increase the proportion of active sites by reducing rare earth oxides to cluster molecules and loading them onto conductive carbon-based materials. Based on density functional theory (DFT) calculation, the graphene-supported La2O3 cluster (La2O3-Gra) was designed as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for ORR and OER, with graphene as the substrate and the nanocage cluster cleaved from the hexagonal La2O3 crystal as the dopant. Firstly, the stability of various configurations of La2O3-Gra was discussed, and a few typical configurations were selected for follow up study. Secondly, the effects of different adsorption sites and hydroxylation on catalytic activity of La2O3-Gra were studied. Finally, we performed an inductive analysis of the adsorption free energy of each reaction intermediate and found the descriptors that rapidly predict the catalytic activity of La2O3-Gra, providing a fresh perspective for the development of electrocatalysis. 2 Computational details 2.1 Model construction Bravis’ law states that the actual crystal faces are parallel to the surface of the crystal with the highest atom density [52]. Therefore, the atom density of cubic lanthanum oxide crystal face was calculated; the results are given in Table 1 . It can be seen that the atom density on the surface of ( 1 1 2 ¯ 0 ) , ( 1 2 ¯ 1 0 ) and ( 2 1 ¯ 1 ¯ 0 ) is the highest in parallel, indicating which is the actual face of the crystal. Therefore, as shown in Fig. 1 , based on the actual external surface, the smallest cage-like cluster was cleaved from the cubic lanthanum oxide crystal, which has been shown to be highly symmetric and stable in previous studies [53]. The reduction of lanthanum oxide to atomic size results in an unsaturated coordination property, which tunes the electronic structure, thereby affecting catalytic performance. In addition, the supercell containing one (5 × 5 × 1) graphene sheet was used as a support for the La2O3 cluster. To avoid spurious interaction between neighboring layers, the thickness of the vacuum layer was set to 30 Å. 2.2 Calculation parameters All DFT calculations of La2O3-Gra system were performed by the DMol3 module on Material Studio software [54]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [55] with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) model [56] was opted to optimize the models of La2O3-Gra and related adsorption configurations. We used the DFT-D with Grimme parameters to modify the van der Waals interactions [57]. The conductor-like screening model (COSMO) [58] was adopted to simulate an H2O solvent environment for all calculations with a dielectric constant of 78.54. Since La is a heavy element with many (57) electrons, the density-functional semi-core pseudo-potential (DSPP) approximation was used [59]. The convergence criteria of the structure were set as follows: energy tolerance of 1.0 × 10−5 Ha, maximum displacement tolerance of 0.05 Å, and maximum force of 0.02 Ha·Å−1. The Monkhorst-Pack K-point grid was chosen as 5 × 5 × 1 to ensure the accuracy of calculation results. 2.3 Computational content In this paper, the stable load configurations were selected by the binding energy (ΔEb) [17] between La2O3 cluster and graphene. The formula is as follows: (1) Δ E b = E G r a + E L a 2 O 3 − E L a 2 O 3 − G r a Where E L a 2 O 3 − G r a represents the total energy of La2O3-Gra, E G r a and E L a 2 O 3 represent the total energy of the graphene and La2O3. The adsorption energies (ΔE*ads) of adsorbates such as O2, OOH, O, OH and 2OH were calculated by Ref. [5]: (2) Δ E * a d s = E * a d s − E * − E a d s Where E * a d s represents the total energy of the system in which the catalyst adsorbs the intermediate such as O2, OOH, O, OH and 2OH, respectively. E* and Eads are the energy of clean catalyst and intermediate, respectively. The adsorption free energies (ΔG*ads) of oxygenated intermediate, including OOH, O, OH and 2OH, were calculated by Ref. [60]: (3) Δ G * O O H = G * O O H − G * − ( 2 G H 2 O − 3 2 G H 2 ) (4) Δ G * O = G * O − G * − ( G H 2 O − G H 2 ) (5) Δ G * O H = G * O H − G * − ( G H 2 O − 1 2 G H 2 ) (6) Δ G * 2 O H = G * 2 O H − G * − ( 2 G H 2 O − G H 2 ) Where G * , G * O O H , G * O , G * O H and G * 2 O H are the free energy of catalyst and adsorbed intermediates, including OOH, O, OH and 2OH, respectively. In alkaline environment, the 4e− ORR could be divided into two paths as follows: P1: (7) O 2 + * + H 2 O + e − → * O O H + O H − (8) * O O H + e − → * O + O H − (9) * O + H 2 O + e − → * O H + O H − (10) * O H + e − → * + O H − P2: (11) O 2 + * + H 2 O + e − → * O O H + O H − (12) * O O H + H 2 O + e − → * 2 O H + O H − (13) * 2 O H + e − → * O H + O H − (14) * O H + e − → * + O H − The reaction energy ΔGi for step i was calculated by Ref. [61]: (16) η O R R = M a x ( Δ G i ) / e + 0.402 (17) η O E R = M a x ( Δ G i ) / e − 0.402 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Stability analysis of La2O3-Gra electrocatalyst High stability helps to prevent degradation of catalytic activity or even complete inactivation caused by the accumulation of La2O3 cluster aggregates during the long-term work. Thus, there is a need to investigate the stability of graphene-supported La2O3 clusters. Based on different loading forms, the configurations were divided into three types: point load (O-Gra and La-Gra), line load (Line-Gra) and face load (Face-Gra). In the case of O-Gra, all the different configurations were considered, and only three were found, namely O-Gra-1∼3. In the case of La-Gra, only three configurations were found: La-Gra-1∼3. In the Face-Gra condition, only two (Face-Gra-1∼2) were observed. In the case of Line-Gra, because the graphene substrate has a stronger adsorption strength for O than La, all of the Line-Gra geometries considered were converted to O-Gra, and no stable structures were found. Table S1† lists all configurations found and the corresponding ΔEb. In the case of O-Gra, the ΔEb is 5.04, 4.76 and 4.76 eV for O-Gra-1∼3, which indicates that O-Gra-1 is the most stable O-Gra structure. The Corresponding ΔEb values of La-Gra-1∼3 is 3.82 eV, 3.85 eV and 3.70 eV, respectively, suggesting that La-Gra-2 is the most stable of the three. The ΔEb of Face-Gra-1∼2 is 4.65 eV and 4.43 eV, respectively, meaning that Face-Gra-1 is the most robust. Overall, O-Gra is the most stable, followed by Face-Gra, whereas La-Gra is the low stable. The presence of the O-C bond is more conducive to improving the stability of La2O3-Gra, meaning that the La-Gra configuration may change in the long-term work. The respective optimal O-Gra, La-Gra and Face-Gra structures are visualized in Fig. 2 , which are selected for follow-on research. From the binding energy, O-Gra-1 has the highest stability, Face-Gra-1 is the second and La-Gra-2 has relatively low stability. This implies that O-Gra-1 is the most likely configuration to be obtained in the experimental synthesis, while La-Gra-2 is less likely to be obtained. Therefore, the activity of O-Gra-1 essentially determines the performance of the entire system. We performed a simple O2 adsorption test, and found that the configuration of La-Gra-2 changed after the adsorption of oxygen, so La-Gra-2 was excluded. (See next section for details). In addition, in order to prevent La2O3 clusters from migrating in long-term work, which may lead to the reduction of catalyst stability, it is necessary to calculate the energy barrier for cluster migration on the graphene surface. As can be seen from Fig. S1†, for the most thermodynamically stable O-Gra-1, the La2O3 cluster has to cross through the energy barrier of 0.46 eV to proceed to the adjacent loading position; and that of the metastable Face-gra-1 only needs to overcome the energy barrier of 0.20 eV, indicating that the O-Gra-1 is the most difficult to migrate in long-term work, followed by Face-Gra-1. we have considered the band structures of O-Gra-1 and Face-Gra-1. As shown in the Fig. S2†, the band gap of O-Gra-1 and Face-Gra-1 is 1.967 and 2.001 eV, respectively, indicating that they are semiconductors. Next, we carried out Mulliken charge analysis. As shown in Fig. S3†, the graphene of O-Gra-1 receives 1.506 electrons from the La2O3 cluster, and that of Face-Gra-1 receives 1.595 electrons from the La2O3 cluster, indicating that there is a strong electron transfer between the graphene and the La2O3 cluster. Due to the strong electronegativity difference between La and O atoms, the La atoms can provide electrons for oxygen containing species and thus become the active center of the catalyst. Furthermore, it can be found that the closer to the graphene substrate, the more positive charges La atoms carry, which will also become one of the main factors for their differences in the adsorption strength of reaction intermediates. 3.2 Mechanisms of ORR and OER on bare La2O3-Gra electrocatalyst In this section, we discussed the reaction pathways and mechanisms of ORR and OER at the different active sites on the bare O-Gra-1, La-Gra-2, and Face-Gra-1. It can be shown in Fig. 2 that there are six active sites on the La2O3 cluster, and the sites in the same layer are equivalent, so that they could be divided into different types; that is, O-Gra-1 can be divided into the up and down sites, Face-Gra-1 can be divided into the up, middle and down sites, while La-Gra-2 only be divided into the up and middle without down because of which undertakes the task of connecting the graphene substrate. Based on Sabatier's principle, a good catalyst cannot adsorb to reaction intermediates either too strongly or too weakly [62]. Since the adsorption of O2 is the key to the onset of ORR, and since its desorption is also an indispensable part of OER circulation, we first calculated the oxygen adsorption at the active sites. As shown in Fig. 3 , O2 can be adsorbed onto a single active site with both the side-on and end-on form, or dual sites at the same time with the bridge-on form. For O-Gra-1 and Face-Gra-1, the adsorption mode of end-on is permanently changed to side-on after optimization due to the strong adsorption of O2 on the catalyst, and the adsorption intensity of bridge-on is always less than the corresponding side-on mode because space constraints, all of which indicate that the main mode of O2 on catalysts is side-on. However, in the case of La-Gra-2, it can be seen that after the optimization of the O2 adsorption configuration, the loading form of La2O3 has changed severely, indicating that the La-Gra-2 is unstable with respect to the others. Its instability is also reflected in the binding energy Fig. 2. Thus, the La-Gra-2 configuration was excluded. The adsorption models for various reaction intermediates on O-Gra-1 and Face-Gra-1 were optimized on the basis of the adsorption of O2 with the side-on mode. For each adsorbate, the adsorption energy (ΔE*ads) and the adsorption free energy (ΔG*ads) were calculated, their effects on the catalytic performance were discussed, and the free energy plots of the reaction were thus obtained. The results are as follows: 3.2.1 Bare O-Gra-1 Fig. S4† shows the electrocatalysis process of bare O-Gra-1, from left to right is the ORR process, and the reverse is the OER process. Table S2† lists the optimal configurations as well as the corresponding ΔE*ads and ΔG*ads of the reaction intermediates. In the case of the up sites, the ΔE*ads of O2, OOH, O, OH, 2OH are −1.66 eV, −2.36 eV, −4.03 eV, −3.54 eV and −5.55 eV, respectively; and the ΔG*ads of OOH, O, OH, 2OH are 3.11 eV, 2.01 eV, −0.16 eV and 1.31 eV, respectively. For the down sites, the corresponding ΔE*ads are −1.56 eV, −2.24 eV, −4.80 eV, −3.44 eV and −5.47 eV, respectively; and the corresponding values of ΔG*ads are 3.26 eV, 1.32 eV, −0.18 eV and 1.26 eV. It can be seen from ΔE*ads that O2 and OH are more likely to be adsorbed at the up sites. However, the up sites are far away from the graphene substrate, which is difficult to transfer electrons, so the possibility of electrocatalysis is small. It is noteworthy that due to the open space and relative position of the active sites on the La2O3 cluster, it is difficult for the adsorbate to cross the high-energy barrier from one site to the next. Thus, even though the binding strength of adsorbate adsorbed at one site is slightly less than that at the other, it is still stable, and the possibility of its reaction is still large, which could not simply be overlooked. The reaction energies for each step of the electron under zero potential in alkaline were calculated from the adsorption free energy of the reaction intermediates. The reaction step diagrams were determined as shown in Fig. 4 . For the up sites, the ORR potential determination step (PDS) of both P1 and P2 is the last step of *OH → *+OH− with ηORR of 1.39 V. In terms of the reverse reaction of the ORR, the PDS of P1 for OER is *OH → *O which has to conquer the energy of 1.34 eV, whereas the PDS of P2 is *OOH → O2 which only has to overcome the energy of 0.99 eV with ηOER of 0.58 V. As with the up sites, the PDS of P1 and P2 at the down sites is also the last step of *OH → OH with ηORR of 1.41 V. While the P1 for OER is smoother, which the PDS is *O → *OOH with ηOER of 0.70 V; the reason for this is that the *O on the down sites has a synergistic effect with the substrate, thus strengthening its adsorption strength and smoothing the energy change from *OH to *OOH. However, in general, the electrocatalytic activity of both the up and down sites is not good, which may be related to the difficulty of OH desorption. 3.2.2 Bare Face-Gra-1 Fig. S5† shows the electrocatalysis process of bare Face-Gra-1. Table S3† exhibits the geometric configurations as well as the corresponding ΔE*ads and ΔG*ads of reaction intermediates for different active sites on bare Face-Gra-1. The ΔE*ads of O2, OOH, O, OH and 2OH at the up sites are −1.91 eV, −2.57 eV, −4.33 eV, −3.74 eV and −5.86 eV, respectively; and corresponding ΔG*ads of OOH, O, OH and 2OH are 2.90 eV, 1.76 eV, −0.46 eV and 0.88 eV, respectively. For the middle sites, the corresponding ΔE*ads are −1.88 eV, −2.53 eV, −4.31 eV, −3.78 eV and −5.94 eV, the corresponding ΔG*ads are 2.82 eV, 1.73 eV, −0.46 eV and 0.62 eV. And for the down sites, the corresponding ΔE*ads are −1.62 eV, −2.32 eV, −4.86 eV, −3.52 eV and −5.52 eV, the corresponding ΔG*ads are 3.11 eV, 1.29 eV, −0.33 eV and 1.13 eV. In general, the binding strength of the reaction intermediates on Face-Gra-1 is higher than that of O-Gra-1, meaning more difficult products desorption. For the Face-Gra-1 itself, the adsorption strength of O2 at the up and middle sites is similar, but obviously stronger than that at the down sites, implying that the adsorbates are more likely to be adsorbed at the up and middle sites. But similar to O-Gra-1, the up and middle sites are far away from the graphene substrate, so it is difficult to transfer electrons to continue the electrocatalytic reaction. As shown in Fig. 5 , regardless of whether P1 or P2, the PDS at the up, middle and down sites is the last step: *OH → OH- with ηORR of 1.69 V, 1.69 V and 1.56 V, respectively. As for OER, the favorable route at the up sites is P2 which the PDS is*2OH → *OOH with ηOER of 0.79 V; the difficulty degree of P1 and P2 at the middle sites is similar with ηOER of 0.96 V and 0.97 V, respectively, while the more accessible passageway at the down sites is P1 with ηOER of 0.60 V because of the presence of synergistic O. But in general, the bifunctional electrocatalysis performance of bare Face-Gra-1 is poor. 3.3 Mechanisms of ORR and OER on OH modified O-Gra-1 and Face-Gra-1 Recently, the theory of OH ligands modifying catalysts has received extensive attention. Theoretical calculations show that OH ligand can effectively improve the catalytic activity, and the introduction of OH ligand also makes the theoretical calculation results agree well with the experiment [61,63–72]. At the same time, the existence of OH ligand is also proved experimentally, which provides a strong factual basis for the OH ligand theory. For example, Cao et al. reported the atomic-level identification of the dynamic structure of catalytically active sites under alkaline. The O–H stretching peak becomes much stronger for Co1/PCN under the open-circuit condition by FTIR analysis, indicating considerable adsorption of OH species on the Co site. Further, the XANES analysis excludes H2O adsorption, suggesting that the Co site should chemically adsorb OH radicals under the open-circuit condition [73]. Also, Yang et al. verified the existence of OH ligand on Fe-N4 sites with the evaluation of pH-dependent ORR activity as well as pH-dependent poisoning kinetics [74]. Based on the research in the previous section, the active sites on the bare La2O3-Gra have a strong OH adsorption, which is likely to result in the hydroxylation of the catalyst. Furthermore, the La2O3 cluster has the feature of multiple adsorption sites; After hydroxylation at one of the sites, the other can continue to take part in the reaction. Therefore, the effect of the hydroxylation on La2O3-Gra was discussed. 3.3.1 OH modified O-Gra-1 The adsorption energy of OH at the up sites of bare O-Gra-1 is less than that at the down sites, which means the stronger adsorption. In addition, the up sites are far away from the graphene substrate, which are not conducive to electron transfer. Therefore, the optimal site for OH coordination of O-Gra-1 is the up sites. As shown in Table S4†, taking the up sites as an example, when it is modified by an OH ligand, the adsorption of the next adsorbent at other sites is far greater than the coordination site, which means that the possibility of electrocatalysis at the OH coordination site is small, so the OH coordination site is not considered as a reaction site. Fig. S6† shows the electrocatalysis process of OH modified O-Gra-1. Once one of the up sites (O-Gra-1-up) has been modified by OH group, the remaining active sites can be classified into three types: up-up, up-down1 and up-down2. The ΔE*ads and ΔG*ads as well as relevant oxygenated intermediates are given in Table S5†. For the up-up sites, the ΔE*ads of O2, OOH, O, OH, 2OH are −0.58 eV, −1.42 eV, −2.63 eV, −2.58 eV and −3.88 eV, respectively, and the ΔG*ads of OOH, O, OH, 2OH are 3.92 eV, 3.45 eV, 0.79 eV and 2.64 eV. For the up-down1 sites, the corresponding ΔE*ads are −0.65 eV, −1.43 eV, −3.70 eV, −2.58 eV and −3.93 eV, respectively, and corresponding ΔG*ads are 3.97 eV, 2.22 eV, 0.72 eV and 2.62 eV. And for the up-down2 sites, the corresponding ΔE*ads are −0.66 eV, −1.44 eV, −3.69 eV, −2.57 eV and −3.96 eV, respectively, and the corresponding ΔG*ads are 3.96 eV, 2.14 eV, 0.75 eV and 2.71 eV. In comparison to bare O-Gra-1, the adsorption strength of each of the adsorption intermediates can be found to be significantly reduced to a more suitable level. For ORR, appropriate O2 adsorption ensures the effective O2 activation, reduction of OH adsorption allows it to be rapidly desorbed and ultimately promotes the catalytic progress. For OER, appropriately decreased OH adsorption will not affect its activation; weakened O2 adsorption contributes to its removal, and OH adsorption is still stronger than O2 adsorption due to synchronous adsorption decay, so it speeds up the catalytic reaction even more. Return to O-Gra-1-up, after hydroxylation, the O2 adsorption at the up-down1 and up-down2 sites is more solid than that of up-up, and the down sites are easy to transfer electrons, indicating that ORR is more likely to occur here. As shown in Fig. 6, the PDS at the up-down1 and up-down2 sites, whatever P1 or P2 is both the last step: *OH → OH− with ηORR of 0.51 V and 0.48 V. The better passageway at the up-up sites is P2 with the ηORR of 0.44 V, while the PDS of P1 is *OOH → *O with ηORR of 0.75 V due to the absence of synergistic *O. For OER, although the adsorption strength of OH is similar, the closer the reaction site is to the substrate, the easier it is to accept electrons, which means the faster the catalytic rate. The best processes at the up-down1 and up-down2 sites are P1 with ηOER of 0.52 V and 0.59 V, and that at the up-up sites is P2 with ηOER of 0.63 V. Although the OH group is more likely to become a ligand at the up sites, it cannot be ignored as a ligand at the down sites. As with the up sites, when hydroxylation occurs at the down sites, the rest of the active sites could also be divided into three types: down-up1, down-up2 and down-down. Because OH group on the down sites is more readily available to accept the electron for reaction in the former as it is closer to the graphene substrate, both two down-up types (down-up1 and down-up2) will be converted to up-down types (up-down1 and up-down2) upon reaction equilibration. So only the down-down sites have to be discussed. The corresponding ΔE*ads at the down-down sites are −0.82 eV, −1.51 eV, −3.65 eV, −2.54 eV and −3.50 eV, and corresponding ΔG*ads are 3.90 eV, 2.34 eV, 0.77 eV and 3.16 eV, respectively. It can be seen that similar to the hydroxylation at the up sites, the adsorption capacity of catalyst for all adsorbates decreased. Furthermore, because the down sites are in close proximity to the substrate, the synergistic effect strengthens the adsorption of O atom, so that the major pathways for ORR and OER are P1 with ηORR of 0.46 V and ηOER of 0.34 V. Overall, because of the stronger adsorption and more difficult electron transfer, the up sites are the optimal site for OH coordination for O-Gra-1. The down sites are an excellent place for electrocatalysis because of easier electron exchange. When one of the up sites was modified by OH group, the up-down1 site shows outstanding bifunctional catalytic activity with η of 0.51 V and 0.52 V for ORR and OER respectively. Also, even other reaction sites still show good catalytic performance. We also discussed the stability of OH ligands. As shown in Fig. S7†, in an alkaline environment with a pH of 14, a large amount of energy is released when a up site generates the first OH ligand, indicating that the reaction is easy to occur. However, it needs to absorb a large amount of energy to continue to generate the second OH group at the same site, which means that only one OH ligand can stably exist at a site. When there is an OH ligand at a up site, others, such as the up-down1 site, continue to generate an OH, which releases a small amount of energy. This indicates that the second OH may exist as a reaction intermediate, but it is unlikely to exist stably as a ligand of the catalyst. Furthermore, under the assumption that both OH ligands can exist stably, other sites, such as up-down1-down2, needs to absorb a large amount of energy to continue to generate the third OH, indicating low reactivity. In addition, we have made Pourbaix diagrams about the electrocatalysis at down sites after the OH coordination at up sites. As can be seen in Fig. S8†, the OH ligand at up sites is stable throughout the whole electrocatalysis process, regardless of up-down1 or up-down2 sites and the reaction path. When the pH is 14, the OH ligand will fall off only when USHE is less than −0.99 V. Therefore, only one OH ligand can stably coordinate with the single site of O-Gra-1, and only one OH ligand can stably exist in O-Gra-1. 3.3.2 OH modified Face-Gra-1 In comparison to O-Gra-1, the OH specie on Face-Gra-1 has three passivation positions: up, middle and down. The OH adsorption of the up and middle sites are significantly greater than that of the down sites, which means that the probability of OH coordination at the down sites is small. The OH adsorption of the up and middle sites is similar, but the up sites are more far away from the graphene substrate, which is more difficult to accept electrons. Therefore, the optimal site for OH coordination is the up sites. Similar to O-Gra-1, as shown in Table S6†, taking the up sites as an example, it can be found that the possibility of electrocatalysis at the OH coordination site is small, so the OH coordination site is not considered as a reaction site . Fig. S9† shows the electrocatalysis process of OH modified Face-Gra-1. Table S7† lists the adsorption configurations of oxygenated intermediates at different active sites of Face-Gra-1 modified by OH ligand. When the OH is modified at the up sites (Face-Gra-1-up), there are four possible reaction sites: up-up, up-middle, up-down1 and up-down2. For the up-up sites, the ΔE*ads of O2, OOH, O, OH and 2OH are −0.71 eV, −1.55 eV, −2.77 eV, −2.70 eV and −4.02 eV, and the ΔG*ads of OOH, O, OH and 2OH are 3.90 eV, 3.15 eV, 0.56 eV and 2.46 eV, respectively. For the up-middle sites, the corresponding ΔE*ads are −0.74 eV, −1.62 eV, −2.78 eV, −2.77 eV and −4.10 eV, and corresponding ΔG*ads are 3.78 eV, 3.19 eV, 0.64 eV and 2.46 eV, respectively. For the up-down1 sites, the corresponding ΔE*ads are −0.91 eV, −1.69 eV, −3.69 eV, −2.58 eV and −1.02 eV, and corresponding ΔG*ads are 3.66 eV, 2.41 eV, 0.57 eV and 3.28 eV, respectively. And for the up-down2 sites, the corresponding ΔE*ads are −0.92 eV, −1.68 eV, −3.69 eV, −2.60 eV and −0.99 eV, respectively, and corresponding ΔG*ads are 3.73 eV, 2.37 eV, 0.75 eV and 3.18 eV, respectively. From the adsorption strength of each reaction intermediate on the catalyst, the up-down1 and up-down2 sites have stronger O2 adsorption than that of up-up and up-middle sites, indicating a higher possibility for ORR. Also, the adsorption ability of O atom at the up-down1 and up-down2 sites is stronger than that at the up-middle and up-up sites, which is due to the synergistic effect of atom O at the two up-down sites. While the adsorption intensity of 2OH at the up-down1 and up-down2 sites is weaker than that at the up-up and up-middle sites, this is because of the weakening of the adsorption capacity of the catalyst following hydroxylation as well as the steric hindering effect of the down sites. As shown in Fig. 7, in the above two cases, the best ORR route at the up-down1and up-down2 sites is P1 with ηORR of 0.66 V and 0.48 V, and the best OER path is P1 with ηOER of 0.61 V and 0.39 V, respectively. While the most favorable way at the up-up and up-middle sites is P2 with η of 0.67 V and 0.59 V for ORR, and 0.67 V and 0.59 V for OER. Once the OH is modified at the middle sites, there are three possible reaction types: middle-up, middle-middle and middle-down sites. Although the OH adsorption strength at the up and middle sites is similar, the middle sites are closer to the substrate and easier to transfer electrons for reaction. The OH group has a tendency to passivate at up sites. As a result, the middle-up sites were excluded. For middle-middle site, the ΔE*ads of O2, OOH, O, OH and 2OH are −0.73 eV, −1.60 eV, −2.98 eV, −2.90 eV and −4.15 eV, and the ΔG*ads of OOH, O, OH and 2OH are 3.87 eV, 2.92 eV 0.43 eV and 2.40 eV, respectively. For the middle-down sites, the corresponding ΔE*ads are −0.91 eV, −1.66 eV, −3.70 eV, −2.58 eV and −0.94 eV, and the corresponding ΔG*ads are 3.64 eV, 2.38 eV, 0.59 eV and 3.14 eV. For the middle-middle site, the best path is P2 with ηORR of 0.80 V and ηOER of 0.75 V. And the most facile pathway at the middle-down sites is P1 with ηORR of 0.64 V and ηOER of 0.56 V. With regard to the down sites with the least opportunity for OH modification, there are also four possible reaction types: down-up1, down-up2, down-middle and down-down sites. Similarly, the down-up1, down-up2 and down-middle sites were excluded due to the stronger adsorption strength of OH at the up or middle sites and the relative position with the substrate. For the remaining down-down site, the ΔE*ads of O2, OOH, O, OH and 2OH are −0.89 eV, −1.63 eV, −3.70 eV, −2.53 eV and −1.15 eV, and the ΔG*ads of OOH, O, OH and 2OH are 4.02 eV, 2.55 eV, 0.95 eV and 3.23 eV, respectively. The major reaction pathway is P1 with ηORR of 0.33 V and ηOER of 0.37 V. Similar to O-Gra-1, the up sites are the optimal site for OH coordination and the down sites are excellent place for electrocatalysis for Face-Gra-1. When one of the up sites was modified by OH group, the best reaction site (up-down2) shows excellent catalytic performance with ηORR of 0.48 V and ηOER of 0.39 V. And other reaction sites also show good catalytic performance. Also, as shown in Figs. S10† and S11†, the reaction energies for the formation of OH ligands and the Pourbaix diagram analysis show that only one OH ligand can stably coordinate with the single site of Face-Gra-1, and only one OH ligand can stably exist in Face-Gra-1. 3.4 The descriptors for evaluating catalyst performance for ORR and OER Based on the research of Nørskov et al., the inherent catalytic activity will be determined by the adsorption strength between the intermediate and the catalyst. For this reason, the ΔG*ads of reaction intermediates (*OOH, *O, *OH and *2OH) were used as the descriptors to evaluate the performance of catalysts for ORR and OER. As can be shown in Fig. 8 (a–c), strong linear relationships are observed between the ΔG*ads of OOH, O, 2OH and OH on both the bare and hydroxylated catalysts. The ΔG*OOH could be expressed as a function of ΔG*OH by Δ G * OOH = 0.81 Δ G * OH + 3.30 eV with a coefficient of determination (R2) of 0.93. The ΔG*O needs to be divided into two types: Ordinary *O (ΔG*O') and synergistic *O (ΔG*O''), the ΔG*O' could be expressed as a function of Δ G * O ′ = 1.39 Δ G * O H + 2.34 e V with the R2 of 0.99, and the ΔG*O'' could be expressed as a function of Δ G * O ″ = 1.05 Δ G * O H + 1.56 e V with the R2 of 0.99. As for *2OH, most of the G*2OH could be expressed as the function of Δ G * 2 OH = 1.55 Δ G * OH + 1.54 eV with the R2 of 0.98, Some *2OH at about 3.2 eV belongs to *HOOH species, and their adsorption free energy is irregular with ΔG*OH due to space constraints and some other reasons. In addition, we also performed the partial density of states (PDOS) analysis. We calculated the f-band center (εf) of La atoms in different environments. It can be found from Fig. S12† that there is a strong scale relationship between εf and the adsorption free energy of intermediates. The closer the εf is to the Fermi energy level, the weaker the adsorption of La atom on intermediates. Different load modes, different active sites and the presence or absence of OH ligand will lead to different electronic structures of the active centers, thus showing different adsorption capacities. Based on the solid scaling relationship between ΔG*ads of OOH, O, 2OH and OH above, the volcano plots for ORR and OER could be constructed. In the system, the PDS of the optimal path in P1 and P2 is always *+O2 → *OOH or *OH → *+OH−, so the volcano plot of ηORR vs. ΔG*OH can be obtained, as shown in Fig. 8(d). The volcanic plot for OER should be divided into two paths: P1 and P2. The ηOER of P1 could be described by ΔG*O-ΔG*OH; also, because of the existence of two kinds of *O, two volcanic plots can be obtained. It can be seen in Fig. 8 (e) that the peak overpotential of the synergistic oxygen is smaller, which means that synergistic oxygen is more conducive to OER. And ηOER of P2 could be described by ΔG*2OH-ΔG*OH as shown in Fig. 8 (f). We can find that different load modes, different active sites and the presence or absence of OH ligand will result in the different distribution in volcano plots, which means that they have a large effect on catalytic activity. This provides a judgment for rapidly evaluating the performance of catalysts with similar structures in the future. 4 Conclusion In summary, the catalytic performance of ORR and OER of La2O3-Gra in the alkaline environment was studied by DFT calculation in this paper. The La2O3 cluster is able to stably exist in the O-Gra and Face-Gra forms, of which O-Gra is the most stable and Face-Gra is metastable. The bare catalyst adsorbs too strongly to the intermediates, whereas hydroxyl modification can effectively reduce adsorption to an appropriate extent. As a result of the hydroxylation of O-Gra-1, the optimal catalytic site (up-down1) shows outstanding bifunctional catalytic activity with ηORR of 0.51 V and ηOER of 0.52 V. And the best active site of OH modified Face-Gra-1 (up-down2) exhibits excellent performance with ηORR of 0.48 V and ηOER of 0.39 V. All this means that the electrocatalytic performance of the La2O3-Gra can be comparable to the commercial Pt-based catalysts and the Ru/Ir oxides OER catalysts. In addition, we have found descriptors to assess the activity of La2O3-Gra catalyst for both ORR and OER, which provide powerful references for the rapid prediction of catalytic activity of similar systems in the future. coredata.dc:description: The development of bifunctional oxygen electrode electrocatalysis for both the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) plays a vital role in the solution of the energy crisis as well as the environmental pollution. The purpose of this paper is to investigate the potential of graphene-supported lanthanum oxide clusters (La2O3-Gra) as a bifunctional electrocatalyst; the results show that the optimal catalytic site (up-down1) of the most stable configuration (O-Gra-1) modified by OH group shows outstanding bifunctional catalytic activity with ηORR of 0.51 V and ηOER of 0.52 V, which can be compared to the commercial Pt-based ORR catalysts and the Ru/Ir-oxides OER catalysts. Furthermore, there is a strong scale-dependent relationship between the adsorption free energy (ΔGads) of reaction intermediates, resulting in volcano plots between the catalytic activity and ΔGads, which provides a valuable description for future performance prediction of structurally similar catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: The graphene-supported Lanthanum oxide cluster as efficient bifunctional electrocatalyst for oxygen reaction
